post_text: Did you know that March is “Music In Our Schools Month?” The National Association for Music Education (NAfME) is encouraging all schools to promote and support musical education. This year all students at MTES participated in a "Music Makes Me...." prompt that is hanging in our hallways. Our students shared many interesting insights into how music makes them feel, e.g., happy, feel good, feel safe, try hard, creative, express myself, and magical, to name but a few responses by our students. To quote Ms. Allen, MTES Music Teacher, “It makes my heart sing to know that the students in our MTES community feel that way about music. We work hard to make sure that music is relatable and accessible to all students and that they all have equal opportunities to perform. We thank you for your continued support of Music at MTES!”

Recently, the students in second grade at MTES have been studying "Local Government" as part of their Social Sciences curriculum. While their lesson plans are carefully aligned with educational standards, to make these learnings fun and realistic, Mrs. Sarah Neibart, Mendham Township Mayor, and Mr. Nick Monaghan, Deputy Mayor, graciously accepted the school’s invitation to visit with the Grade 2 students and discuss local government right here in Mendham Township.

Armed with the knowledge from their Social Sciences classes, these students asked relevant and focused questions of our local leaders, a key educational objective for their grade. Mayor Neibart and Deputy Mayor Monaghan participated in a lively interactive session that even included a voting exercise, where every student got to submit one vote for their favorite pet, i.e., dog or cat!

Thanks go to Mrs. Sarah Neibart, Mendham Township Mayor, Mr. Nick Monaghan, Deputy Mayor, and Mrs. Darlyne Pieper, Grade 2 Teacher at MTES who arranged this event.

In a buildup to the one hundredth day of school, parents/guardians of kindergarten students have been busy collecting food and household items to be donated to the Interfaith Food Pantry. All four kindergarten classes gathered together to apply their newly acquired counting skills and determine if they had reached their goal of donating 100 items. With happy voices counting out loud, these young students realized early that not only had they easily met their goal, but they had surpassed it with 258 items!

Mrs. Allen and the Fish Class, Mrs. Kelly and the Bears Class, Mrs. Merlino and the Busy Bees Class, and Ms. Williamson and the Superstars Class would like to say thank you to everyone who helped make this a happy and thoughtful event.

post_text: June 5, 2019 was a picture-perfect day at MTES for holding the 2nd grade Writing Picnic. Parents brought blankets and snacks to the school’s side lawn so that they could spend the afternoon with their second grader. The picnic provided a relaxed and fun setting for the children to share their portfolio compiled of their second grade writing across many genres. During the school year, these students learned to write simple essays, which include a beginning, middle, and end. Students became aware of the importance of including a title and developing a clear introductory sentence for each essay so as to engage their readers and correctly position the content of their writing. They practised crafting these essays so that they can now research a topic and provide examples and details that support their main concept and end with a concluding sentence. What a nice way for parents and their children to create some special memories as they share in celebrating these students’ accomplishments.

Spring is definitely here. With the guidance and planning skills of Mrs. Erica Parke and Mrs. Tracy Newton, last Thursday (April 18, 2019), students were busy donning gardening gloves, selecting hand tools, and opening microgreen seed packets to sow new plants in the MTES garden. Mrs. Parke explained that these nutritious, fast-growing greens are considered baby plants. Similar to baby lettuces, baby carrots, etc., these plants can grow quickly with very little tending. The microgreens were planted by gently turning over the earth, sprinkling some seeds, and letting Mother Nature take care of the rest. The anticipated weekend of rain was perfect timing to help these little seeds take root and grow. Even better, all grade levels at the school got to participate and to have their own planting area. Students planted peas, kale, radish, green lettuce, spinach, and arugula.

Our thanks to Mrs. Parke, Mrs. Newton, and all the volunteers who helped our students discover their "green" thumbs!

Look for this space to become green!

With the guidance and planning skills of Mrs. Erica Parke and Mrs. Tracy Newton, last Thursday (April 18, 2019), students were busy donning gardening gloves, selecting hand tools, and opening microgreen seed packets to sow new plants in the MTES garden. Mrs. Parke explained that these nutritious, fast-growing greens are considered baby plants. Similar to baby lettuces, baby carrots, etc., these plants can grow quickly with very little tending. The microgreens were planted by gently turning over the earth, sprinkling some seeds, and letting Mother Nature take care of the rest. The anticipated weekend of rain was perfect timing to help these little seeds take root and grow. Even better, all grade levels at the school got to participate and to have their own planting area. Students planted peas, kale, radish, green lettuce, spinach, and arugula.

Our thanks to Mrs. Parke, Mrs. Newton, and all the volunteers who helped our students discover their "green" thumbs!

Look for this space to become green!

Did you feel a little bit like a time traveler on Friday, April 5, 2019? If yes, you must have been at MTES Colonial Crafts Day. Students from the 4th grade, their Moms and Dads, immersed themselves in the heritage of Mendham by recreating a day filled with activities from colonial times. Everyone can learn history, but not many students have the opportunity to live it.

Dressed in period costumes, students from the 4th grade enthusiastically participated in learning crafts that would have been extremely important for surviving in the early 18th century. How could you perform your household chores of collecting eggs for your Mom unless you had learned how to weave a basket to carry the eggs! How could you see at night unless you had learned how to make candles? It wasn’t all work, as the students learned. Flying kites was a popular diversion when the weather was warmer and designing your own kite was a great way for children to entertain themselves.

We thank our students, their parents, and all the volunteers who helped this a wonderful, living example of history.

Wearing full Indian costumes, four dancers performed a variety of high-energy, choreographed numbers. The melodies are simple, encouraging everyone to join in; the rhythms are soothing but energetic, making a task easier to complete as people go about their work. Our thanks to the Cultural Arts Assembly team for hosting this educational and entertaining event.

The technique of impasto can help the artist manipulate light, infuse expression and feeling, and add depth and texture to a painting. Stop by the hallway in MTES with Mrs. Bizzaro’s classroom to see this absolutely amazing interpretation of “Starry Night” by these young MTES artists. They are breathtaking!

Inspired by the adventures of Pete The Cat, the children used their growing knowledge of colors and shapes by coloring pictures of Pete The Cat or created their own representation of this character. Some students gave him six buttons to make him look extra groovy while they were learning about the number six. Pre-K and kindergarten children recently attended a Pete The Cat Performance at the Mayo Performing Arts Center in Morristown, NJ. Here’s some of the preschoolers’ creations celebrating Pete The Cat!

post_text: Students in the third grade are currently learning how to analyze the technique and painting style of impressionist, Vincent Van Gogh. Under the guidance of Mrs. Sarah Bizzarro, students learn about the lives of different artists and how each artist expressed their feelings and creativity through their art. Mrs. Bizzarro’s classes create a carefully crafted balance between teaching students how to appreciate and understand what a famous artist wanted to communicate via their work and also inspiring these budding artists at MTES to use their own imagination and talent to create new individual works of art! After analyzing and discussing Van Gogh’s famous “Sunflowers,” the students chose to work in either warm or cool pastel colors to create their own art piece. The students also applied mark-making technique to create different textures and add depth and contrast to their compositions.

post_text: Recently, students in Second, Third, and Fourth Grade were treated to a “Book Tasting” at the MTES School Library, hosted by Ms. Tracy Newton, MTES Media Specialist. While a popular idea, Ms. Newton has extended this idea as an opportunity to collaborate with the local Mendham Township Library in building young people’s interest in reading. The school library was redecorated to resemble a charming restaurant, the "Tiger Cafe," with the exception of having stacks of books on each round table. Each table featured a different literary genre, e.g., non-fiction, fantasy, realistic fiction, historical fiction. Students spent five minutes seated at each table and got to sample several books that were featured at a particular table and could be checked out at the local Mendham Township Library or at the MTES School Library. While browsing the menu students received gentle prompts to consider what they like about a book and what was surprising or interesting about a book. What a great way to create an appetite for reading!

post_text: From pie plates to pie charts, 3rd Graders enjoy learning how to create graphical displays of data. First, they start with a plate and some Skittles. Second, they sorted and created tallies of the five different colors. Next, they converted their tallies to a frequency table. This included finding the sum of the different color candy pieces. Then they calculated the proportion each candy color represented of the whole number of Skittles. Finally, they used the original pie plate to draw a circle and used the data to represent the distribution of candy in a pie chart. This last step included eating the Skittles as a reward for all that hard work! See if you can match the image with the sequence of steps.

The students experience success early in their literacy endeavors which leads to increased confidence and interest in continuing to build their reading skills. It may look like an interesting skyline of an unidentified city, but if you look closely you will see that the windows in the skyscrapers are really arrays. Look even closer and you will see that the arrays are labeled and correctly calculated by the students. An array is an arrangement of items in rows and columns. As part of the third grade curriculum, students are building their multiplication skills. Drawing arrays helps a student visualize equal groups of objects and then they can confirm their answer by counting the individual objects.
